repnme.cdata!: Romania - Employment and Social Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey satisfactory project
            outcomes, likely sustainability, and high institutional
            development impacts. Key lessons address the following. Like
            many of the first generation of projects in the transition
            countries, the project design was fairly complex, and, to a
            large extent, the rationale for the high complexity derives
            from the comprehensive set of recommendations included in
            the Bank's report "Human Resources and the
            Transition to a Market Economy in Romania". While the
            statement that a less ambitious project design would have
            allowed an easier and faster implementation may be accepted,
            it would be fair to say that in the end, the efforts paid
            off, since all the project development objectives were
            satisfactorily achieved. Donors involvement in project
            preparation strongly helped the process, and secured as well
            a significant amount of valuable technical assistance,
            delivered during implementation, on a grant basis, for the
            development of employment services, adult training, career
            counseling, and active labor market measures. Stakeholders
            participation (trade unions and employers associations) was
            also highly helpful in building consensus, and ensuring
            active support and participation during project
            implementation. However, the coordination of the large
            number of implementing agencies (Government and
            non-Government) involved in implementing the various project
            components, placed a heavy burden on the Project Unit,
            particularly at the early stages, when the consultative
            process was still not definitely established.

repnme.cdata!: Romania - Employment and Social Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Employment and Social Protection
            Project will support the Government's efforts to
            alleviate unemployment and poverty, improve the efficiency
            and affordability of employment and social protection
            services, and promote labour productivity and economic
            competitiveness. The specific objectives of the project are
            to: 1) strengthen the capacity of labor offices to
            administer increasing numbers of claims for unemployment
            benefits and active labor adjustment services (e.g. job
            placement, employment counseling, training); 2) develop a
            flexible adult training system which responds to evolving
            labor market demand resulting from economic restructuring;
            and 3) implement reforms in social insurance and assistance
            programs, targeting those population groups which are most
            vulnerable to falling into poverty during and after the
            transition to a market economy. Project components include:
            1) General management and policy including monitoring and
            policy analysis of new programs, automation of labor and
            social protection offices to support and improve the
            management of programs to be introduced, and project
            management support to expand and strengthen the already
            functioning Project Coordination Unit established under the
            Technical Assistance and Critical Imports (TACI) Project; 2)
            employment and training which comprises employment services,
            career information and counseling, and adult training; and
            3) social protection.
